column3: he had a dog called Romeo
column4: who was made to do the work of churning butter. I never saw a churn that went by dog-power; but it must have been a clumsy affair.The task could not have been an agreeable one
column5: and I do not wonder that Romeo did not like it. One morning
column6: when the churn was taken out
column7: and the cream was all ready to be made into butter
column8: there was no Romeo to be found. Long and loud were the calls made for him; but he did not answer to his name.The churning was done that day without his help. Nothing was seen of him until just before dark
column9: when he came into the house with the air of a prodigal son. He did not walk up like an honest dog to get his supper
